note: uncalibrated), whereas the Elko Side-notched, which Holmer (1986) describes as the Archaic low side-notched form, is contemporaneous with the Elko Corner-notched (7950–600 B.P., uncalibrated).
title: low side-notched points, a temporal pattern emerges. High side-notched points, such as Northern Sidenotched, San Rafael, Sudden, and Rocker, date between 7450–3450 B.P

note: Eighty percent (n = 41) of the Elko Side-notched points date between 5500–1000 cal B.P.
title: The current sample includes 51 Elko Side-notched dart points collected during excavations at 18 sites. Representative points are shown in Figure 31. Three of the Elko Side-notched projectile points were collected during excavations at site 5MF3006 and all have a midpoint date of 4875 cal B.P. The Elko Sidenotched temporal distribution is slightly shorter than the Elko Corner-notched form, with a midpoint date range for all of the Elko Side-notched points of 6865–775 cal B.P. and a mean date of 3870 cal B.P

note: The Rosegate points that predate 2000 cal B.P. are considered anomalies in the dataset, as it has been noted that small, arrow-like points do appear in Archaic-age assemblages (Metcalf 2011a).
title: Seriation, or battleship, graphs were produced to illustrate the temporal distribution of the projectile point types in the dataset. The dart point graph demonstrates that many of the Archaic era projectile points initially appear in the archaeological record between 7000–6000 cal B.P

with only the Elko Corner-notched, Pinto, and Sand Dune Side-notched types appearing earlier. The Elko Side-notched, San Rafael Stemmed, and McKean Lanceolate initially appear between 7000–6500 cal B.P., while the Gatecliff Contracting Stem, Northern Side-notched, Elko Eared, and Duncan-Hanna, emerge sometime between 6500–6000 cal B.P. Figure 44 shows that Rosegate points commonly appear between 1750–1500 cal B.P., while the other arrow points become more widespread after 1250 cal B.P

note: were assigned to a specific, 500-year period (e.g., 1500–1000 cal B.P., 2000–1500 cal B.P.) and those predating 3000 cal B.P. were assigned to a
title: In an effort to analyze the distribution and changes to the mean basal width over time, each projectile point was assigned to a specific 500-year or 1,000-year interval depending on its calibrated midpoint date (Figure 46). Those points dating from the present day to 3000 cal B.P

Because bow-and-arrow technology is believed to begin sometime after 2000 cal B.P., those points predating 3000 cal B.P. certainly represent dart points and do not require the same refined, temporal division as the later-dating projectile points

note: seen in gray in Figure 47), with the widespread appearance of arrow points occurring after 1600 cal B.P.
title: How the data in Figure 46 and Figure 47 correlates with the projectile point typologies will be presented in further detail below, but the analysis thus far has demonstrated a decline in overall basal width sometime after 2000 cal B.P. Based on the clustering present in Figure 47, it is proposed that the transition from bow-and-arrow technology occurred between 2000–1600 cal B.P

title: Great Divide Pioneer 8500–6600 9500–7500 Opal Settled 6600–4750 7500–5500 Pine Spring Transitional 4750–3000 5500–3250 Deadman Wash Terminal

note: Thompson and Pastor 1995) and expands Metcalf ’s (2011b) recent permutation, but is consistent with the Northern Colorado River Basin Context
title: By default, the precursor Great Divide/Pioneer period would then be 9500–7500 cal B.P. The data also indicates that the Pine Spring/Transitional period be fitted from 5500–3250 cal B.P., which would encapsulate most of the known Archaic basin houses and mark the end of the use of large thermal features
This Pine Spring/Transitional period narrows the Wyoming definition

note: Formative Era As defined elsewhere, the Formative era (e.g., Fremont) refers to a block of time with marked technological
title: The Deadman Wash/Terminal period should then include the remaining block of time in the Archaic era from 3250–1700 cal B.P. As discussed below, the date of 1700 cal B.P. is strongly suggested by the succeeding Formative era. Although it is expected that future data will improve on the interpretations presented here, there appear to be consistent shifts in the archaeological record that mark useful changes for regional and local cultural taxonomies (Table 104

note: when settlement patterns shifted (e.g., the use of basin houses), changes in diet breadth occured (i.e., increased hunting of artiodactyls), pottery was used, and the bow and arrow were introduced (Reed 2011b; Reed and Metcalf 1999; Thompson and Pastor 1995).
title: advancements and shifts in subsistence strategies (Reed 2011b; Reed and Metcalf 1999; Thompson and Pastor 1995). Although there are no Fremont sites in the pipeline corridor, the Formative era represents a period of time when pottery and the bow and arrow are utilized, when agriculture was integrated into regional economies, and when populations increased (Reed 2011b; Reed and Metcalf 1999; Thompson and Pastor 1995). In a recent summary, Reed (2011b) distinguishes between the Aspen Tradition of northwestern Colorado (1700–600 cal B.P) and the Uinta Phase of the Wyoming Basins (1600–650 cal B.P.), though the differences are nominal and center on a difference in settlement systems. For all intents and purposes, the Formative era, whether in Colorado or Wyoming is defined from 1700–600 cal B.P

container-title: Colorado, the Protohistoric era (650–69 RCY B.P.) marked the end of horticultural-based subsistence practices and the expulsion of the Ute to reservations in A.D. 1881
note: Reed and Metcalf 1999:146). Later, Reed (2011a) proposed acceptance of Wyoming’s Protohistoric-era archaeological units for northwestern Colorado: including the Firehole period (550–275 cal B.P.), the Protohistoric Period (275–140 cal B.P.), and the Historic period (140–69 cal
title: Because of an overlap with Euroamerican documentation, the timing and naming conventions of the Protohistoric era has seen the most discussion. As defined in Wyoming, the Protohistoric period originally included two pre-Historic-era phases; the Firehole phase (650–250 RCY B.P.) and the Protohistoric period (300–150 RCY B.P.) (Thompson and Pastor 1995:62–63). The Firehole phase represented a post-Fremont, pre-Shoshone period with decreasing populations and subsequent shifts in subsistence and technological practices. The Wyoming Protohistoric period marked the introduction of European goods in artifacts and was strongly associated with Shoshone occupations

Constitution grants the national government ‘supremacy’ in policy making for the ‘general welfare’ of the
The Department of State, Department of the Treasury, Office of the Attorney General, and the Post Office under the constitution were established

The Department of the Interior was established to manage all domestic policy, including the exploration of western lands, the regulation of territorial governments, Native American policies, and public lands
The Department of Agriculture was formed and was referred to by Lincoln as the ‘people’s department,’ and was charged with implementing farming, agriculture, and food policies
The Department of Justice was established for enforcement of federal laws
The Interstate Commerce Commission (ICC) was created to regulate the railroad industry, prevent railroads from charging excessive fares, and required consistent fees for shipping
The Department of Agriculture was raised to cabinet level
The Bureau of Immigration was established under the Treasury Department to implement national immigration laws and to be responsible for the admission or rejection and processing of all immigrants
The Department of Commerce was created to promote economic growth
FDR’s New Deal established government jobs and welfare programs, including the Civilian Conservation Corps
